description:
### Document name - AWSFIS-Run-Memory-Stress

## What does this document do?
It runs memory stress on an instance via stress-ng tool. If stress-ng is not already installed on the instance, this SSM document will install it, unless InstallDependencies parameter is set to False.
This SSM document supports Amazon Linux and Ubuntu operating systems only.

## Dependencies installed by this SSM Document
* stress-ng
* pgrep
Note: This SSM document does not uninstall dependencies once installed. If you don't want this SSM document to install any dependencies, set InstallDependencies to False and bake the dependencies into your EC2 instance. For example, by using image-builder (https://aws.amazon.com/image-builder/).

## Input Parameters
* DurationSeconds: (Required) The duration - in seconds - of the fault injection.
* Workers: The number of virtual memory stressors (default: 1).
* Percent: The percentage of virtual memory to use (default: 80).
* InstallDependencies: If set to True, Systems Manager installs the required dependencies on the target instances (default: True).

## Output Parameters
None.

DurationSeconds.description: (Required) The duration - in seconds - of the fault injection.

Workers.description: The number of virtual memory stressors (default: 1).

Percent.description: The percentage of virtual memory to use (default: 80).

InstallDependencies.description: If set to True, Systems Manager installs the required dependencies on the target instances (default: True).

mainSteps.name: InstallDependencies
mainSteps.description:
## Parameter: InstallDependencies
If set to True, this step installs the required dependency via operating system's repository. It supports both
Debian (apt) and CentOS (yum) based package managers.

runCommand:
#!/bin/bash

set -o errexit

#################################
#       Dependency Logic        #
#################################

function install_sch_netem_module() {
  ssm_working_dir=$(pwd)
  # Work from a directory that Amazon SSM Agent creates
  cd /etc/amazon/ssm/
  current_working_dir=$(pwd)
  kernel_version=$(uname -r)
  # Default location of sch_netem module
  sched_module_local_path=/lib/modules/"$kernel_version"/kernel/net/sched/
  sch_netem_kernel_module_file=sch_netem.ko
  # Check if there is no compressed and uncompressed version of the module
  if [ ! -f "${sched_module_local_path}$sch_netem_kernel_module_file" ] && [ ! -f "${sched_module_local_path}$sch_netem_kernel_module_file".xz ]; then
    echo "sch_netem does not exist, installing"
    # We will download and install the sch_netem kernel module to avoid the need for a reboot, as
    # would be required if we used `yum install kernel-modules-extra`.
    temp_dir=kernel-lib
    # If the yumdownloader comes back with no module available, then fail
    if yumdownloader kernel-modules-extra-"$kernel_version" --destdir "$temp_dir" 2>&1 | grep "No package kernel-modules-extra-$kernel_version available."; then
      echo "No sch_netem module for the kernel version $kernel_version"
      echo "Exiting - Unable to install sch_netem. kernel module sch_netem must be installed for this document to run"
      rm -rf "$temp_dir"
      exit 1
    fi
    # We need to CD into the temp_dir for cpio since it does not work with absolute or relative paths well
    cd "$temp_dir"
    # Unpacks the modules into lib/
    # version is downloaded but will differ from $kernel_version, depending OS.
    rpm2cpio kernel-modules-extra-"$kernel_version".rpm | cpio -id
    # Move back to the working dir.
    cd "$current_working_dir"
    # if sch_netem exists in the rpm lib, move it to /etc/amazon/ssm
    sch_netem_path=$(find "$temp_dir"/lib -name "$sch_netem_kernel_module_file".xz)
    if [ -n "${sch_netem_path}" ]; then
      echo "Downloaded Kernel Modules, and sch_netem exists. Loading Module"
      mv "${sch_netem_path}" "$current_working_dir"
      # Do not need the rest of the temp_dir
      rm -rf "$temp_dir"
      echo "Unpacking sch_netem"
      xz -d "$sch_netem_kernel_module_file".xz
      rm -f "$sch_netem_kernel_module_file".xz
      # Create a symlink to the default location so that the module can be added to the list of available modules by depmod
      ln -s "$current_working_dir"/$sch_netem_kernel_module_file /lib/modules/"$kernel_version"/"$sch_netem_kernel_module_file"
      echo "Loading sch_netem"
      # Refresh the list of available modules
      depmod -a
      modprobe sch_netem
      # Check if loaded successfully
      if lsmod | grep -wq "sch_netem"; then
        echo "$sch_netem_kernel_module_file module installed and loaded"
      else
        echo "Exiting - Error loading module, kernel module sch_netem.ko must be installed for this document to run"
        exit 1
      fi
    else
      # make sure our temp file deleted.
      rm -rf "$temp_dir"
      echo "Exiting - Unable to install sch_netem. kernel module sch_netem must be installed for this document to run"
      exit 1
    fi
  # Check if the module exists and enable it
  elif [[ -f "${sched_module_local_path}/$sch_netem_kernel_module_file" ]]; then
    if modinfo ${sched_module_local_path}/$sch_netem_kernel_module_file -F vermagic | awk '{print $1}' | grep -Fi "$kernel_version"; then
      # Lets build an updated list of available modules first
      depmod -a
      # Insert module
      modprobe sch_netem
    fi
  # if the compressed module exist, uncompress and enable
  elif [[ -f "${sched_module_local_path}$sch_netem_kernel_module_file".xz ]] && [ ! -f "${sched_module_local_path}$sch_netem_kernel_module_file" ]; then
    # Module exists, so we need to unpack it and insert the module in the kernel it
    xz -d -k "${sched_module_local_path}/$sch_netem_kernel_module_file".xz
    if modinfo ${sched_module_local_path}/$sch_netem_kernel_module_file -F vermagic | awk '{print $1}' | grep -Fi "$kernel_version"; then
      # Lets build an updated list of available modules first
      depmod -a
      # Insert module
      modprobe sch_netem
    fi
  fi
  cd "$ssm_working_dir"
}

function check_and_install_netem() {
  if ! lsmod | grep -wq "sch_netem"; then
    # To avoid issues with SELinux we wrap everything in sudo.
    # In order to call the install_sch_netem_module function wrapped with sudo,
    # we need to pass it as a command rather than a function call.
    SUDOINSTALL=$(declare -f install_sch_netem_module)
    sudo bash -c "$SUDOINSTALL; install_sch_netem_module" 2>&1
    # Check if loaded
    if lsmod | grep -wq "sch_netem"; then
      echo "sch_netem.ko Module loaded"
    else
      echo "Exiting - Error loading module, kernel module sch_netem.ko must be installed for this document to run"
      exit 1
    fi
  fi
}

function adjust_rhel_package() {
  # For centos/rhel 7 the package is iproute, so remove the suffix if iproute is there
  # since this command is directly related to the use of sch_netem.
  if [[ ${rhel_package} == *iproute-tc* ]] && [ "$os_major_version_number" -eq "7" ]; then
    rhel_package=${rhel_package/iproute-tc/iproute}
  fi
}

# Configure ATD service if required
configure_atd() {
  if ! systemctl is-enabled atd || ! systemctl is-active atd; then
    echo "Enabling and starting atd"
    systemctl enable atd
    systemctl start atd
  fi
}

########################################################################################################################
 # This script builds a list of available modules and enables sch_netem                                                #
 # sch_netem kernel module is responsible for emulating traffic,                                                       #
 # FIS SSM Documents use this module when creating network faults, such as the packet loss fault and the latency fault #
########################################################################################################################
# Build a list of the available modules
enable_netem() {
  if ! command -v depmod &> /dev/null; then
    echo "WARN depmod is not available. Command could fail due to missing sch_netem"
    return 0
  else
    depmod -a || echo "enable_netem() - WARN depmod -a failed, continuing anyway"
    # Enable the sch_netem module, if there is a failure, exit
    if ! modprobe sch_netem; then
      echo "WARN Cannot enable sch_netem"
      echo "WARN Command could fail due to missing sch_netem"
      return 0
    fi
  fi
  return 0
}

# Check if dependencies are already installed
check_existing_dependencies() {
  if [[ "$( command -v stress-ng 2>/dev/null )" && "$( command -v pgrep 2>/dev/null )" ]]; then
  
    echo "Dependencies are already installed."
    exit
  
  fi
}

validate_installation_settings() {
  if [[ "{{ InstallDependencies }}" == False ]]; then
    echo "Missing dependencies detected with InstallDependencies set to false. Please install dependencies ["stress-ng", "pgrep"] or set InstallDependencies to true for supported operating systems." >&2
    exit 1
  fi
}

# Handle Amazon Linux installations
install_amazon_linux() {
  if ! grep -Fiq 'VERSION_ID="2023"' /etc/os-release; then
  
    # Use amazon-linux-extras if available (Amazon Linux 2)
    command -v amazon-linux-extras 2>/dev/null 1>&2 && amazon-linux-extras install testing
  
    yum -y install stress-ng procps-ng
  elif grep -Fiq 'ID="amzn"' /etc/os-release && grep -Fiq 'VERSION_ID="2023"' /etc/os-release; then
  
    yum -y install stress-ng procps-ng
  else
    echo "Exiting - This SSM document supports: Amazon Linux 2023, Amazon Linux 2, Ubuntu, CentOS 9 and RHEL (8, 9) operating systems"
    exit 1
  fi
}

# Handle RHEL/CentOS installations
install_rhel_centos() {
  # Fetch OS Version
  os_version_number=$(grep -oP '(?<=^VERSION_ID=).+' /etc/os-release | tr -d '"')
  # if the version has a decimal, this line will remove it
  os_major_version_number=${os_version_number%.*}
  # Replace with version number in the url if required
  if ! rpm --quiet -q epel-release; then
    epel_dl_url="https://dl.fedoraproject.org/pub/epel/epel-release-latest-VERSION.noarch.rpm"
    epel_with_version="${epel_dl_url/VERSION/$os_major_version_number}"
    yum -y install $epel_with_version
  fi
  rhel_package="stress-ng procps"
  
  yum -y install $rhel_package
}

# Handle Ubuntu installations
install_ubuntu() {
  apt-get update -y
  # when installing, sometimes ubuntu has stderr that are not breaking errors.
  install_error=$(apt-get install -y stress-ng procps 2>&1)
  if [[ -n "$install_error" ]]; then
    echo "$install_error"
  fi

  ubuntu_commands=( stress-ng pgrep )
  for dependency_command in "${ubuntu_commands[@]}"; do
    if ! command -v $dependency_command >/dev/null 2>&1; then
      echo "Exiting - $dependency_command not installed"
      exit 1
    fi
  done
}

# Main function to orchestrate the installation process
main() {
  check_existing_dependencies
  validate_installation_settings

  echo "Installing required dependencies"
  trap 'status=$?; if [ $status -eq 1 ]; then echo "Failed to install dependencies. Please retry or manually install dependencies ["stress-ng", "pgrep"] and set InstallDependencies to false." >&2; fi' EXIT

  if [ -f "/etc/system-release" ] && grep -i 'Amazon Linux' /etc/system-release; then
    install_amazon_linux
  elif grep -Fiq 'ID="centos"' /etc/os-release || grep -Fiq 'ID="rhel"' /etc/os-release; then
    install_rhel_centos
  elif grep -i "Ubuntu" /etc/issue; then
    install_ubuntu
  else
    echo "Exiting - This SSM document supports: Amazon Linux 2023, Amazon Linux 2, Ubuntu, CentOS 9 and RHEL (8, 9) operating systems"
    exit 1
  fi
}

# Execute main function
main

mainSteps.name: FaultInjection
mainSteps.description:
## Parameters: DurationSeconds, Workers and Percent
This step will run a memory stress test on the instance for the specified DurationSeconds time.
It will start `Workers` number of workers, using `Percent` of the total available memory.

runCommand:
#!/bin/bash
set -o errexit -o errtrace -o nounset -o pipefail

#####################################
# General pre fault-execution logic #
#####################################

# To track how long the fault command took to run
start_time=$(date +%s)

########################
# Fault-specific logic #
########################

validate_parameter_within_range() {
  local parameter=$1
  local value=$2
  local min=$3
  local max=$4

  if (( value >= min && value <= max )); then
    return 0
  fi

  echo "Parameter $parameter must be between $min and $max, was: '$value'" >&2
  exit 1
}

validate_process_not_running() {
  local process_name="$1"

  # Check if process is running
  if pgrep "$process_name" > /dev/null; then
    echo "Another '$process_name' command is running, exiting..." >&2
    exit 1
  fi

  return 0
}

validate_parameter_within_range "DurationSeconds" {{ DurationSeconds }} 1 43200
validate_parameter_within_range "Percent" {{ Percent }} 1 100
validate_process_not_running stress-ng

echo Initiating memory stress for {{ DurationSeconds }} seconds, {{ Workers }} workers, using {{ Percent }} percent of total available memory...
stress-ng --vm {{ Workers }} --vm-bytes {{ Percent }}% -t {{ DurationSeconds }}s
echo Finished memory stress.

######################################
# General post fault-execution logic #
######################################

# Function to check if a fault execution ran for the expected duration
# Returns 0 if the fault execution ran for at least the expected duration
# Exits with code 1 if the fault execution ran for less than the expected duration or if parameters are invalid
run_post_fault_injection() {
  local start_time=$1
  local duration=$2
  
  # Check if start_time is provided
  if [[ -z $start_time ]]; then
    echo "start_time is not defined" >&2
    exit 1
  fi
  
  # Calculate elapsed time
  local elapsed_time=$(( $(date +%s) - start_time ))
  
  # Fail if the fault command exits successfully but the execution duration is less than the expected duration.
  # This happens when stress-ng is killed prematurely using SIGTERM or SIGINT.
  if [[ "$elapsed_time" -lt "$duration" ]]; then
    echo "Fault took $elapsed_time seconds to execute, which is less than expected duration $duration" >&2
    exit 1
  fi
  
  return 0
}
run_post_fault_injection "$start_time" {{ DurationSeconds }}
